segments.text: That Gordy became a very big five percenter in Washington.
He became a representative.
Matter of fact, he became a representative of an air transport association.
and he became a representer of some grain combines and he became a big five percenter.
He made Drew Pearson's column several times.
Really?
Yes.
Somebody tripped, tipped Drew Pearson off as to what happened to Gordon Moore in the military and told him that I could tell him the story.
Drew Pearson called me a couple of times
And a couple of his aides called me a couple of times, trying to get me to tell them the story of George Gordon Moore.
And Moore calls himself, I don't know if, I haven't heard of the guy in three or four years now, but Moore calls himself retired Colonel George Gordon Moore.
He uses the full colonel rank and says he's retired.
Well, to get back, the first time I was nominated,
to be a general officer.
My name was removed at the White House when Eisenhower was the president.
So your name got all the way up to the White House.
It got all the way up to the White House.
In other words, the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Oh, hell yes.
I got all the way out of the Department of the Army and the Secretary of Defense.
At the White House, it's just kind of a rubber stamp before it goes to confirmation.
Sure.
I was told in a very secret channel that my name was removed in the White House.

And then later when I was nominated and it went on through, then I was nominated twice for my second star and I was told by some very good authority the second time when I was in my last command there in Philadelphia that
some friends of General Eisenhower had seen to it that my name was removed at the White House.
Yeah.
That's a fact.
Even though LBJ was in.
Even though LBJ was in, yeah.
And I had a couple of guys that went to LBJ about it, and I knew President Johnson, but it was quite a political ploy.
The chief of staff at that time was a guy named Johnson.
And he wasn't a good friend of mine, but the promotion board had recommended it and I'd been filling a two-star billet in that command for three years.
And so, but my name didn't get through, didn't get up to the Senate.
And even Senator Goldwater,
was all teed off about it.
He was, he told me, I saw him three or four years after that.
As a matter of fact, I saw him when I was working for Scott.
And he said, he said, your second star really, really was kicked around in circles in Washington.
But he said, I admire what you did.
So this is about the most noteworthy thing about my career.
Isn't it a shame when someone's honest?
But I'm proud to have done it because I believe that the least that an individual can do is to
is to serve with dignity and to serve with honesty.
And any son of a bitch that achieves his purpose by utter falsification and deliberate utter falsification, because he had to falsify a transcript and take a photo of it.
He made a fake transcript and then photostatted it.
the university guys admitted that it was the farm that the university used for their transcripts.
Says he must have gotten the farm from somebody in the registrar's office and just typed in all these, and most of the courses that he typed in were correct courses.
So he got a catalog of the university.
Yeah, he got a catalog and gave himself enough course credit to graduate.
So I got a big charge out of it, and I haven't told this story in this detail in a long, long time.
But it was a big thing, and it was a big thing to me at the time.
But it's been a little thing, because since I retired, you know, the fortune has been real good to me.
Well, if there were...
You were just in charge of the military personnel for the quartermaster.
And you found that many discrepancies.
You found 89 discrepancies out of 9,000.
How many discrepancies did the entire army find?
Did they carry out their own investigations?
Did the military?
No, they didn't.
Or the Navy or Air Force?
Not completely, no.
I would say there are probably several thousand.
officers, most of them probably retired by now, but several thousand officers served under false conditions.
I, I'm sorry to say that, but it's goddamn true.
Oh, why didn't, why didn't the rest of the army take the cue from what you were finding?
I think it, uh, the theory was why rock the boat, you know?
Yeah, why rock the boat?
Everything's
going along smooth, but it always, it irks me to see people get advantage over people that do right, and people get advantage over them by doing wrong.

Because there was so damn many, and I know people I served with during the war, that just wanted to be in the regular service, but were not accepted in the integration, and yet there was some sum of bitches that were crooks,
that got it, and these good people didn't have the opportunity to serve.
And this is what bothered me.
So I really, but I've done very, very well since I left the service.
I walked out of my office in Philadelphia, my command in South Philly,
Drove out to the airport to Scott's corporate headquarters and was a corporate vice president.
Had about twice the salary that I was making then as a general officer and served there for three years and could have stayed on until I retired.
But this opportunity opened up down here and I came back down here and made an accommodation to take over this business.
Well, so it's been very rewarding.
I was wondering about something else that's in a sense similar to this, and it was also going on in Washington around 1950, and that is McCarthyism.
Yeah.
And in what way did McCarthyism affect the Army, as far as you're concerned?
Did it have any impact on you as chief of personnel for the quartermaster?
I don't believe that it did.
McCarthyism, I think, there's a... McCarthyism exists today.
It's a malady.
And the use of the word following the name of the man that so personified those traits and those ethics.
I don't think that McCarthyism per se really
had a big impact on the army.
I think that military people have got to function in a fishbowl and have got to function with integrity and honesty because ultimately the people in the country have their ultimate faith
in what the military can do for them.
The military are supposed to be the final protectorate of the way of life and the perpetuation of the country.
And if the people in the country can't have respect for the military, why, I think we're in a bad way.
And I think that one way that
we can ensure that they have respect for the military, is for the military people to serve honorably and to carry on their life and their decorum in an honorable way.
Well, what about the fact that Senator McCarthy charged that there was a Red General in the Army, a Brigadier General?
I think he was a supply officer, as a matter of fact.
Yeah, I don't know.
And then Secretary of Army Stevens had to go to Congress, which was one of the downfalls of McCarthy and all the hearings.
Yeah, this guy, this officer was supposed to have been at Fort Monmouth, I think.
Signal Corps, yeah.
I had met the guy, I forget the name.
I do too.
I forget it, but I had met him.
Bob Stevens, the Secretary of the Army that you alluded to there, I know him very well.
Robert T. Stevens, who had been the Secretary, because he was the titular head of J.P. Stevens and Company, a big textile, and I got to know him very well and in my command.
Bob Stevens was a hell of a fine guy.
I think one of the most

noteworthy speeches ranks as far as I'm concerned alongside Lincoln's Gettysburg Address was during the McCarthy hearings when the army lawyer made that statement to McCarthy when McCarthy chastised this young lawyer that worked for Welch and Welch looked at him and said Mr. McCarthy you and your
Venom have done a great damage to a fine young man.
And is there no compassion in your soul at all?
That was really a very dramatic speech that Welch made.
So that was really a big thing in our family and in my circle of friends in the military.
Every once in a while, I'll see somebody and they'll
They'll want to know about Gordon Moore.
But I looked on it very philosophically.
It didn't bother me at all.
In what year were you sent to the Far East?
Okay, so in 1954.
Oh, there's another thing I wanted to ask you before we move on to that.
And that is, as Chief of the Military Personnel for Quartermaster, you must have had some major problems during Korea.
Yes, it was.
What were they?
Calling people to active duty was a major problem.
And the compassionate, nearly everybody had a compassionate problem of they didn't want to come to duty.
And if they did want, they would want
three months or two months or six months so they could get their affairs in order.
And then assigning people to units that were going to Korea was a compassionate, a lot of compassionate thing.
We had a lot of requests for compassionate deferment and compassionate delay of recall and this sort of thing.
It was a real trying time.
It was even, of course I wasn't in, had no personnel actions during Vietnam.
They were all logistic as far as Vietnam was concerned.
I was over there a couple of times.
I've been thinking a lot about Vietnam recently, particularly since the CBS report.
the other day, or a couple of months ago, where they chastised Westmoreland.
And while I wouldn't stand up in front of a big audience and make a speech and say that, there's a hell of a lot of truth in what the CBS had to report.
Oh, we're going to talk about Vietnam.
We'll talk about Vietnam, and we're going to talk about your role, and I want your ideas on it, too.
But let's say that until we get out there.
OK. Why don't we because that's important.
You said that 69 were resigned right on the spot in that Eisen, not Eisenhower, in that Moore affair.
And what happened to the rest of that?
Well, like I said, those 69 resigned.
And 12, we put a memo for record in their file absolving them and saying that the case is closed.
and the others went before board just like Garnie Moore and like he, they were removed from the service without honor and without dishonor.
So there wasn't a single one that survived?
Not a single one survived, not a single one.
And in other words, you were right in all the acquisitions?
We were, we were absolutely right in all of them and minor discrepancies, they're probably

the personnel people that screened the files under the ground rules we laid down said there were probably 500 minor discrepancies where someone had claimed 65 hours of credit when the actual university or college said well they only had 59 hours or 62 hours or something like that.
where they said they'd gone to school for five semesters and maybe they'd only gone four semesters.
And we thought they were minor discrepancies.
And all of them, where there was a discrepancy,

over the actual record and what the FBI background report had shown, we put a statement in their file saying the discrepancy had been accepted and recognized and absolved and the case was closed so that there wouldn't be any continuing going into these things in the future.
Today on where we left off last time, and that was in Japan.
Today is the 17th of August, 1982.
This is our second interview with General Kinderdine.
And you were the commander of the United States Petroleum Facilities in the Far East, and you were stationed in Japan.
Yeah, with headquarters in Yokohama on Tokyo Bay.
And this was a series of petroleum storage and distribution facilities throughout the Japanese islands, including Hokkaido and Honshu and Kyushu.
Honshu being the main island where Tokyo and Yokohama and so forth are located, and Hokkaido, the most northern island,
included in that was one pipeline that was laid from a little port city of Hatchanoi about 35 miles up the beach to an air base and we operated that pipeline.
In addition, the storage facilities that the U.S. built in Okinawa were under our technical supervision and some facilities in Korea likewise were.
All of our facilities in Japan were former patrolling facilities that the Japanese government had built in preparation for World War II.
They were all underground storage tanks, concrete underground storage tanks.
And the Japanese had built some 30 million barrels of underground storage.
And when the war was over,
hardly any of it was even slightly damaged by the extensive bombing because it was hardened.
They were hardened sites and underground.

And therefore we had a beautiful set of terminals and facilities to move into to store the Navy special fuel oil for the fleet and diesel for the fleet and the military and aviation gasoline and jet fuel and motor fuel.
which we brought directly from the Middle East.
Oh, that's what I was going to ask you.
Was this American oil?
90% of it came directly to us by tanker from the Middle East, from Rastanura and ports in the Persian Gulf, and was lifted to us by MSTS tankers and by commercial contract tankers.
Some aviation gasolines came from the west coast U.S. and from Venezuela.
And some motor fuel, very, very little motor fuel came from the U.S. or from Venezuela.
All of that came from the Middle East.
And we operated, we rehabilitated and operated
about 20 million barrel capacity of these underground facilities.
There were several terminals that we made no attempt to rehabilitate them.
Even though they had a little dirty oil and tank bottoms in them, they could have been rehabilitated very easily.
And the job was not just for the Army now.
This was for all of our forces.

For all the U.S. forces, Army, Navy, Air Force, and Marine, the whole U.S. And also we provided support when requested to other NATO members, such as the British, any fleet units they had operating in the area if they needed to have some fuel out.
So it was a joint operation and a very, very extensive one.
We pretty much, we ran our own laboratories to test the quality control on every tanker load and we did a lot of minor research on some fuels.
As a matter of fact, that's where I became so enamored with
The study of jet fuel, turbine fuel, the aviation turbine fuel was in Japan.
I had a very fine laboratory on Tokyo Bay that was staffed by a couple of former professors of chemistry in the university and we ran

And we got so interested in turbine fuel and jet fuel that we investigated several phenomena, one of them being the growth of bacteria in jet fuel, which was showing itself even in some aircraft tanks.
This bacteria grows at the interface between jet fuel and water.
and it was particularly growth, it showed a particular growth when the jet fuel and water had an interface in a concrete tank.
There was something in the concrete walls that seemed to leach out and it was truly a bacteria growth.
I know the first time one of the Japanese chemists showed me this
beaker with jet fuel and water, this thing that looked like the mother on a bottle of vinegar, the thick scum that you often refer to a long time ago as a mother in a bottle of vinegar.
And then he said he believed it was a living organism.
And I said, well, I don't believe it is an inorganic fuel.
So about two weeks later, he showed it to me again, and it was about twice as big as it was.
So I said, I believe you're right, it is a living organism.
And we sent samples to the National Bureau of Standards and several other laboratories.
It had been known before and recognized, but nobody really knew what to do about it.
And some oil companies got busy on it and developed an additive to put in the fuel
that would really prevent this from happening.
But I understand about a year or so ago they had another outbreak of it.
And it was particularly prevalent in Southeast Asia and in the South Pacific for some reason or another.
But anyway, these facilities out there were, it was a very, very satisfying operation and
It was about 1,500 miles from one end of my little command to the other, the furthest terminal on Hokkaido to the furthest terminal on Kyushu.
And we helped to design some underground tanks that the U.S. built in Okinawa.
We sort of patterned them after the Japanese tanks.
The Japanese showed great ingenuity
What they did, they built a standard underground tank which was about 150 feet in diameter and about 90 feet tall with the walls were tapered.
They were thickest at the bottom where the greatest pressure would be because of the standing column of liquid.
And they tapered up to where they were maybe four inches thick at the top.
And the way they did, rather than make an excavation of 90-odd feet and cover it over, they'd find a location near a port of discharge that was kind of hilly with little hills and little ravines.
Then they'd build a tank down in the ravine and then fill in around it, which was a pretty ingenious thing.
way to do it.
I imagine it saved a lot of time.

And they built all this system and from the middle to the late twenties and in the thirties, early thirties, getting ready for the eventual world war that they were going to wage in all of Southeast Asia and the Pacific.
Now how did you get along with the people of Japan?
Very, very well.
The people in Japan
were, I think, easier to work with and better to work with than the Germans in the occupation period.
The Japanese were more subservient, is that the right word for it?
And they're certainly more courteous and more cordial.
You always had the feeling that maybe, you know, they were real nice to you and everything
Maybe if you were sleeping with your back turned to them, they might stick a knife in you, but I don't really believe that.
I got along very well with them.
And the Japanese can be trusted.
I don't think they can be trusted as much as the Chinese.
I think the Chinese have a code of ethics and a code of conduct that's stronger than the Japanese.
But the Japanese, in the true oriental tradition, respect, and you can trust their respect because they would lose face if you didn't.
Now, when you were there, weren't we starting to rebuild their armed forces?
Oh, yes, yes.
The Japanese self-defense forces.
Sure.
We worked very closely with them.
In fact, we had some joint maneuvers with them, joint petroleum supply maneuvers with them.
And I got very friendly with several of the high-ranking officers.
When I left Japan, when I came back to the States, they gave me a big party and came down to the airport when we left and gave me a plaque of appreciation and everything.
I got along very, very well with them.

I've talked to other officers who are in the Orient, especially Korea, and some in Japan, and they said that there's always the problem when you're dealing with the Orient of bribes, which they see more as a standard way to do business.
And of course, in America, we don't.
Did you ever have any
Oh, very definitely.
See, we had a lot of contact with Japanese industry.
I would think so, especially in your position.
Yeah.

For example, one real good one that I made a good lasting friendship that even exists today was with a Japanese contractor over there that rehabilitated steel drums, you know, 55-gallon steel drums, because we had mountains of them.

all sorts of things came to us in drums and they would be issued out to the troops and everything and be emptied and then we'd bring them back in because they represented quite a monetary investment, these 55-gallon steel drums.
So we periodically have to have these things rehabilitated, cleaned out and repainted and new bums put in them and so forth.
And rather than have a facility to do this,
We did it on contract.
And we had this Japanese contractor in the Yokohama, Tokyo area that did a very fine job and did it for a very, very good price.
And we put these out on competitive bid, and nine times out of ten, he would get the business.
His name was Saito, S-A-I-T-O.
I forget the name of his company, but he was Saito himself.
So we got pretty, pretty well acquainted with him and he was constantly wanting to entertain us and wanting us to go to the geisha houses with him and have dinner with him and so forth.
And, but one time I told him, I said, look, no, and he couldn't speak any English, but he had a pretty good interpreter.
a right-handed man and a gal that spoke good English that worked for him.

I said, I won't go to a geisha house with you for a big evening of entertainment and dinner and so forth, but if you and Mrs. Saito will take me and Mrs. Kender down, we'll go with you if you'll make it a family affair.
So this was very strange, very unusual because Japanese men don't take their wives to a geisha house.
And a geisha, a refined geisha house is really not a whorehouse.
The geisha girls, some of them will engage in sexual favors, but mostly a geisha house is a place where you go and eat and the patrons are pampered and they are entertained by the geisha girls.
dances and playing the samisans and all the instruments.
So he finally, they finally agreed that he and Mrs. Saito and his daughter Sachi, they would go with him and then we would bring, I'd bring my wife and bring my son.
He was about 12 years old, I guess.
Yeah.
Anyway.
The daughter, the girl wasn't quite old enough.
So we did.
Went to this swanky geisha house in Tokyo.
And I know the evening must have cost a fortune.
And Mrs. Saito threw her daughter Sachi, who spoke a little, and she said that this is the first time in all her life she'd ever been inside of a geisha house.
None of her Japanese lady friends had ever been to a geisha house.
Oh, they thought it was wonderful.
That gave her something to talk about for months.
Oh yeah, that was really something.
So we established a very good rapport with the family of this contractor.
When we got ready to leave Japan and come back to the States, they gave us a big going away party at their home.
Oh great.
We went to their home.
And just before we were departing, he wanted to make a presento to me.
And he brought out a Canon camera with all the, every kind of lens you can ever think for it.
And I'm sure it had a value of, oh, $1,500, $2,000, something like that.
Had the whole thing all beautifully wrapped up.
And I thanked him for it and so forth.
And then I told him that it's just impossible that I can accept this because it's forbidden
even though it may be strange, sound strange to him, it's just forbidden that we could accept anything like this in my position.
And he was always just crestfallen.
He said, well, can your son, can we give it to your son?
And I said, no, that's just not possible.
So the guy, his aide that spoke to Ingrid said, well, could you just take it overnight, and then tomorrow morning when they meet you at the airport, give it back to me.
And I said, well, yes, we'll do this.
So that it would look like I had accepted it, and then I left it back there with him.
So we did that.
And I would have liked to have taken it, but I just couldn't do it.
Nobody would have known about it, I'm sure, but I just couldn't do it.
But there were a number of examples like that.
Oh, yeah, a number of them.
Were there?
Oh, perfect.

We've gotten, we stayed in contact with the Saitos through the years, and my wife and I went over to Tokyo two years ago, and Mr. Saito is dead, and his wife is dead, but the daughter is still there, and she's married one of the leading movie stars,
In Japan today.
No kidding.
Yeah.
And they came to the hotel.
We stayed at the Nuotani Hotel in Tokyo.
And her husband is a beautiful, good-looking guy.
We had seen his picture in a Japanese commercial on television.
They drove up to that one.
We didn't see him when they drove up, but we had dinner there, luncheon on a Sunday.
And then they wanted to take us out to the Saito home, which they still have.
And he had a Corvette, American Corvette, which cost in Tokyo probably about $50,000.
And they drove us out to their place and showed us a videotape of their wedding.
They had married about a year before.
And they plugged in the video in the Sony and showed us a videotape of their wedding.
And it was quite a, and we corresponded with them since then.
And they're supposed to, last thing we heard, they're supposed to come over to the States.
And we may go out to California and meet them.
But there was lots of examples like that.
And I personally know of a lot of guys that took things from the Japanese.
Not, I don't believe in the,
true sense of a bribe or what have you, but when it comes right down to nuts and bolts, that's exactly what it was, really.
But that's a big thing in the Far East, a very big thing.
What does the military have to say about it?
Well, it's strictly forbidden.
It's strictly forbidden.
It's against all procurement regulations.
It's unethical and it's certainly illegal partisan procurement regulations.
And were there any cases that came up during that time or any examples that the military used?
I believe there was in connection with the exchange system, the post-exchange system.
I believe some civilian employee buyers in the exchange system and maybe an officer or two
were tried by courts martial.
I believe they were, yeah.
But no big deal.
No ranking person.
I know of a pretty high ranking guy in Tokyo that took a lot of favors from Japanese that he shouldn't have taken.
far beyond a casual luncheon or something like that.
I had a couple of luncheons with Saito, but then other times I would take him to the officer's club for lunch and pay for it and so forth.
And how did, how did that, what did the military think when you took a contractor to the officer's club?
That was okay.
That was okay, yeah.
Yeah, that's just,
you know, just professional in business courtesy.
If he was there during the time and you saw it feasible and he was performing the service,
for the military to take him to the club, and of course you pay for it.
He's your guest, just like anybody would do, so there was nothing wrong with that.
Why did you leave Japan?
Your tour of duty was over?
Yeah, tour of duty was over.
And you went to France now.
I came back to the States, came back to the States, and I guess
I then went to headquarters third army in Fort McPherson, Georgia.
And I was there in the southeastern part of the United States and from there
I was selected in a very prestigious selection to go to the Harvard Business School.
I noticed that in 1959.
Yeah, to the Advanced Management program.

And tell me about earlier you, of course, had gone to the Army War College, but most young men in their careers, their ascension, go to the War College, but very few ever go to the Harvard Business School.
Yeah, and it's still true today.
selection the military for since after the war the military and the government have made a practice to our every class of the advanced management program at the HBS
The Army sends two or three people.
The Air Force sends one or two.
The Navy sends one or two, depending upon budgetary situation.
The CIA and the Department of State and Department of Commerce, Department of Interior, between those three or four agencies, there are two or three go.
So they're about...
four to six people from government that are in each class of the Harvard Business School.
And how large are the classes usually?
The classes are about 200, maybe 225.
I think they're a little bit larger now.
And I was in the 36th AMP, Advanced Management Program.
And it has been looked upon since the war
that if you're selected to go to the Harvard Business School, it's almost tantamount that you're going to be selected to flag rank.
In fact, I think the records will show that less than 5% of the people from military or government that go to the Harvard Business School, it's a pretty expensive thing for the government.
Less than 5% have failed to be promoted to flag rank.
In my class, there was only one guy from the military that didn't get flag rank.
He was a fellow from the Transportation Corps.
Very, very brilliant guy.
But anyway, the Harvard Business School, the military pays all your tuition, which even then was quite considerable, and now it's
Well, I think it's about $8,000, $9,000, $10,000 for this five-month course.
It's a five-month course, and is it part of the MBA program there?
Part of the MBA program.
You get a five-month capsule of the two-year MBA program, really.
I see.
And they really give it to you in a very concentrated form and really a high-level form.

But the military, of course, paid my tuition, and they paid me the normal per diem that I would make on temporary duty, which at that time was $15 or $16 a day that they paid us to pay for your meal and your hotel and so forth.
Well, that won't pay for anything.
Hardly, and wouldn't then, in those cases, pay for your board and your meals at Harvard and everything.
So, it's traditional, and this has never been written in a book or anything, but this is traditional, and of course you find this out from guys that have been there.
People from the military and from government are adopted by people from industry
when they go to the Harvard Business School.
In other words, in your class will be vice presidents from Exxon and from General Electric and people that are going to be promoted when they come back to vice president or something.
And even some presidents of small companies or executive vice presidents and so forth.
I didn't know anything about this adoption per se when I went up there.
So I went up there and you're assigned to a group of men.
A group of men are assigned together to what they call a can group.
And a can group are the, I think it's six men that live in six rooms.
that used the same bathroom facilities.
They had one bathroom in this dormitory set up like they had there then, where these six bedrooms and study rooms used the same bathroom.
Very nice, the laboratories and commodes and everything.
Sufficient for six men.
There were two or three commodes and two or three laboratories.
I think there were four laboratories.

We never had any conflict in the bathroom because it was so much, very, very nice, which was between three rooms here, bathroom, three rooms there on a floor, and then above you was the same thing in a stairwell.
So that was your can group, C-A-N, can group, because you use the same can.
That's where it got its name.
So I got acquainted with my guys in the can group.
One of my guys...
while I was there got polio, a very light case of polio, and we all worked on him.

I guess I did more than anybody, massaging him and everything, and of course the Harvard Medical School clinic and everything administered to him, and he had a remarkable recovery from this light case of polio.
Another guy in my can group is today the chairman of Air Products Incorporated, and
Hell of a brilliant guy.
Well, anyway, about the second night I was there, well, I was sitting in my room, and the other five guys came in my room.
I didn't know what the hell was going on.
